awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Deployment of antibacterials as seed treatments
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to alleviate the impact of Bacterial Panicle Blight (BPB) by providing a seed coating treatment that will kill the pathogen before it can cause damage throughout the plant. Rice is a food staple for more than 3 billion people around the globe. Rice diseases affect rice production worldwide, and as a result, represent a significant threat to global food security. Among rice diseases, Bacterial Panicle Blight, caused by the pathogen Burkholderia glumae, is particularly problematic as there are not effective methods to control it. The deployment of this technology may reduce yield loss to farmers due to this disease, while also reducing the costs associated with the purchase and use of antibacterial chemicals that are not effective. This technology may benefit rice farmers in the United States and across the world. Although this project focuses on a specific bacterial disease in rice, it is possible that its impact can be expanded to other crop diseases.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an environmentally-friendly and effective seed coating treatment to control Bacterial Panicle Blight (BPB). Plant diseases caused by microorganisms such as fungi and bacteria significantly affect agricultural productivity. Traditionally, fungal plant diseases have been controlled by synthetic fungicides that while effective, pose significant threat to the environment. In contrast to fungal diseases, effective methods to control bacterial diseases in crops are unavailable, mostly because the use of synthetic antibiotics in crops can increase the likelihood that antibiotic resistance can be transmitted to human bacterial pathogens. There is a critical need to find antibacterials effective against plant diseases without detrimental effects to human health or the environment. Bacterial Panicle Blight (BPB) has significantly decreased rice production worldwide. The proposed technology is based on the secreted fraction of the environmental bacterium Pseudomonas protegens strain PBL3. Because the P. protegens PBL3 secreted fraction contains a mixture of molecules with diverse modes of action, the likelihood that bacteria develop resistance is very small. This technology has the potential to provide an effective, long-lasting, environmentally-friendly and consumer-accepted method of reducing BPB in rice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The technology associated with this project is a biologically-based seed treatment, targeted to protect seeds against a rice disease called Bacterial Panicle Blight (BPB) that has significanlty affected rice production worldwide, and it is forecasted to become more devastating with climate change.

The main goal of this project was to establish the market feasibility of the technology and to understand the pipeline for commercialization. To achieve the main goal, we conducted customer interviews of rice farmers, agronomists, extension agents, regulators and representatives from seed and biotechnolgy companies and located in the United States, Latin America and Asia.

The interviews of farmers, agronomists and extension agents revealed that BPB currenlty does not have the global impact previously anticipated. Only farmers and agronomists in Latin America, view this disease as very problematic and are desperately looking for methods to control it. These results are promising indicating that a potential market for the technology is Latin America.

By interviewing regulators in the United States Department of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Agency, we learned about the regulatory requirements to bring the technology to the market. Interestingly, fewer regulations apply for biologicals, and those fewer regulatory hurdles were pointed out by seed companies representatives as an advantage to decrease the timeline to deploy the technology.

Interviews with seed companies revealed that many companies are incorporating biologicals in their research and development platforms. Morevoer, they pointed out that using biologicals as an additional line of products will significanlty increase their revenues. Importantly, farmers are interested in adopting biologicals especially in the organic market.

We also interviewed representative from biotechnology companies to understand the producion pipeline. It was not possible to calculate the total cost of the production of our biological as scaling up might need to be evaluated empirically.

While our technology has the potential to contribute to alleviate the effects of BPB, the results from this project showed that the market is very small and that additional information is needed to bring this technology to market.

 


Last Modified: 01/11/2024
Modified by: Clemencia   Rojas
